title: Friday, 23rd February, 2018

Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 269.20, down 12.8 (-4.54%), High: 274.00, Low: 268.70, Volume: 9.11m

Swedish Chef Thought Andrew Neil did the Corbyn Spy story rather well. If there was a ref he would have stopped the contest. JC is neither a spy nor (despite initials) the Messiah.
11:08 am
BE11:08am

Costs were 2% higher than consensus

Londonbus @Mouselet - I'm in the heart of the concrete jungle of the city - no idea. It's the weekend here!
BE11:09am

And we get an accelerated transformation plan, whatever that means.

BE11:09am

Well .... what it means is forecast cuts.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

RBC incoming.

Londonbus @BE - faster branch closures? You know RBS is serious when they shut the Natwest Branch in Reigate - deepest Surrey.
BE11:10am

The company guides to a reduction in costs in 2018 but materially lower than the decline in 2017 (£800m in 2017 and
consensus expects £500m decline in 2018 and every £100m is 2% of consensus PBT). RBS has abandoned the £6.4bn 2020 cost target (reflected in consensus) but still targets a 50% cost to income ratio by 2020- implying higher costs than consensus but also higher revenue. RBS expects to take restructuring costs over the next 2 years of £2.5bn which is higher than the £1bn previous guidance and c.£1.1bn in consensus.

rwl @Swedish Chef - if not the Messiah., is he a naughty boy then ?:)
PM11:10am

It's been ten years. Maybe a good idea to accelerate things

Mouselet I am deeply confused how the Stasi archives are supposed to have a bearing on interactions with Czech spies!
Grouchmonkey Re yesterday's discussion on Brexit politics - had dinner with ex-leader of the Tory party last night. He very bullish about limited risk of the discussions all going wrong. Said Barnier was "all bluster"
11:10 am
BE11:11am

The rebuilding of RBS is a very, very long project. Far longer than it took to knock it down in the first place.

Londonbus @grouchmonkey - none of this is looking good re Brexit. Glad I'm outside the UK.
BE11:11am

(@Grouchmonkey: that sounds like IDS.)

Mouselet That sounds deluded
SoS Point is how much can american government screw out of rbs?
Londonbus @BE - it took a long time for Fred the Shred and Matthewson to build in the first place.
Swedish Chef @rwl. Very naughty. Especially if he confiscates my utilities. Neil torturing a minister here http://www.bbc.com/news/av/uk-politics-43145957/steve-baker-on-tory-reaction-to-corbyn-spy-claims

11:12 am

Otter I like Steve Baker
rwl @Swedish Chef - yes saw that i/view - A Neil does surprise all sometimes!
BE11:13am

Operating trends: Adjusted PBT (excluding IFRS vol.) of £685mn, a touch below (3%) to company-compiled consensus, (£707mn) driven by higher provisions within the CMB (with the increase driven by a single name), partially offset by better costs.

BE11:13am

Capital: CET1 up 40 bp to 15.9 (vs 3Q17 at 15.5%), with the increase mainly driven by £10bn reduction in RWAs during the quarter. Consensus was at 14.7% as it assumed a much larger litigation charge (£2.2bn vs £764mn actual). Adjusting for this, we believe capital beat by 40-50 bps.

Londonbus @Grouchmonkey - sounds like he's swallowed the Torygraph's line. Everything's going to be great apparently.
11:13 am
PM11:14am

(Sorry -- just been caught up in UBS's new fangled two-step verification thing. When did they bring that in?)

BE11:14am

Capital guidance: within the release, the group comments it expects to “maintain a CET1 ratio in excess of our 13% target” in the near to medium term. RBS cites a number of factors in relation to this including litigation and conduct, future potential pension contributions, RWA inflation (IFRS 16, Mortgage floors, Basel 3 and increased impairment volatility (IFRS 9). In addition the group also cites the collective impact of these items on its stress test results

Swedish Chef @rwl enjoyed sideswipe at the lab bloke too. STFU.
BE11:14am

(Been there for a while. And, yes, irritating.)

Mouselet I am really not convinced of the wisdom of assuming the EU Parliament and Council to be paper tigers
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Non-ring-fenced bank: in Natwest Markets Plc (the group’s future
non-ring-fenced bank) RBS is targeting an end-state CET1 ratio of 14% and aleverage ratio “greater than 4%”. Natwest Markets Plc is expected to contain c.£50bn of RWAs and a funded asset base of c.£120bn.

rwl RBS Ceo this am on Radio 4 talking about his salary - said it is 3.5. ( left out the millions!)
Londonbus @rwl - millions are the new k...
BE11:15am

TBVPS down 2% to 292p (vs 3Q17 at 299p), mainly driven by litigation charges.

Mouselet I would have thought RBS CEO was absolutely the kind of role that ought to pay minimum wage, some out-of-the-money options, and a knighthood at the end
BE11:15am

The hell is TBVPS? Is it like TNAV?

11:15 am
PM11:15am

Ive no idea

BE11:15am

US RMBS: The group has increased its provision by £0.5bn but provided no incremental information on stage of discussions

Grouchmonkey @BE couldn't possibly say. The message seemed to be positive on everything including education, which I was more dubious about. The feel I get is of the party going into election mode, which is strange.
BE11:16am

Outlook: (i) Additional £1.5bn restructuring costs for 2018-2019, (ii) discontinued absolute cost target of £6.4bn (statutory) in 2020 whilst it retained its 50% C/I target, implying slightly improved outlook on revenues.

Londonbus @mouselet - isn't he Aussie/Kiwi? Why would he haul arse around the world to that sort of job if the money's rubbish?
11:15 am
PM11:16am

(Actually, i have: Tangible Book Value Per Share)

(Ah.)

Mouselet You don't expect a GE in April 2019?
Lefevre Czech Spy - real concern about Corbyn was his fondness for people like Chavez, that wasn't 30 years ago. Tabloid nonsense = free press.
Londonbus @Grouchmonkey - Tories have lost their minds. for a pragmatic party they have become Momentum-like. Not good.
BE11:16am

Anyway, exciting huh? And the good news is that we're at the end of bank reporting season I think.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

So we can forget about them for another three months.

Mouselet Because anyone who would make a plausible bank CEO already has enough money, and you would really prefer the CEO of a somewhat nationalised bank not to be heavily driven by personal gain
PM11:17am

Thumbs up

Swedish Chef Not sure the markets fully price the entire FUBAR that is Brexit. Even Olly (maybots representative on Earth) is learning in the job. Jesus wept.
Mouselet I mean 'has a mortgage such that he needs a million-pound salary to keep it up' ought to be disqualifying for the role
Grouchmonkey @mouselet peanuts. Boss of Snapchat got $600m+ for presiding over a redesign which has users switching off the app!
undefined

However, I guess we need to mention bloody insurance.

Mouselet The fact that some people have done absurd things doesn't make them less absurd!
Standard Life Aberdeen PLC (SLA:LSE): Last: 393.80, up 8.1 (+2.10%), High: 404.30, Low: 384.60, Volume: 10.58m
sprout Corbyn had the kitchen sink thrown at him on his IRA associations in the last elections - seemed to have no impact. Can't imagine Eastern Bloc spy stuff would be any different.
Mouselet (and the boss of Snapchat is presumably mostly paid in shares)
Phoenix Group Holdings (PHNX:LSE): Last: 798.00, up 38.5 (+5.07%), High: 817.00, Low: 763.50, Volume: 1.55m
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Phoenix has found something to buy, as it needs to otherwise it dies.

Londonbus @sprout - Corbyn could have been a baby eater in the 1970s and it would have no effect on his vote.
Mouselet Do I have a bad memory, or has Phoenix Group Holdings never featured in this august discussion?
Mouselet ... isn't the expropriation of Anbang the single biggest insurance story?
BE11:19am

And Aberdeen has dumped the insurance business it tried to dump previously into a Scottish Widows JV.

Swedish Chef When I was VERY young I had an endowment mortgage with standard life. I like to think I’m wiser now.
BE11:20am

Probably most interesting to look at from the Phoenix side initially. Deal is £2.9bn, which is pretty much Phoenix's market cap.

Grouchmonkey @mouselet yes, I think it's mostly stock and that may not be worth $600m by the end of the year....
sprout Mouselet - Bloomberg made interesting point that a year ago that would have panicked markets, now it's a sign of China being in control of its deleveraging process
11:20 am
BE11:21am

Or £3.2bn depending on how you price all the moving parts, which include £1bn of vendor finance.

BE11:21am

And SLA getting a 20% shareholding in Phoenix.

Twas ever thus What about all the FTSE insurance JV's in China and HongKong ?
Lemmy Mouselet: several Chinese billionaires have not been seen in public for some time now
BE11:22am

Brokers happy-ish. Here's Numis.

tadam There were tens of thousands of people "signed" up for reporting to agencies in the Eastern bloc, internally and externally. That didn't make them spies and these people didn't get compensated. Corbyn was spreading Soviet propaganda in the 80's and he is likely to have been a friendly asset that didn't make him a spy.
11:22 am
BE11:22am

This appears to be a very good deal for Phoenix, adding
significant future cashflows, and priced at just 84% of Standard Life Assurance’s estimated Solvency II Own Funds of £3.5 billion, in line with recent transactions.

BE11:23am

And Barclays. Who go though the hard numbers.

BE11:23am

Phoenix estimates that its annual dividend capacity will increase to £338m from current £197m. A £338m annual dividend at the current dividend yield of 6.5%, is a £5.2bn market cap – an equivalent market cap to FTSE 100 insurance Admiral (£5.4bn) and Direct Line (£5.3bn). Phoenix estimates that the dividend, pro –forma for the equity raise and Standard Life Aberdeen’s 19/9% stake, is equivalent to a 3% increase. However, the flow of new business from Standard Life Aberdeen, coupled with its bulk annuity aspirations, will lead to a much more stable cash generation to support the dividend. The company also confirmed it is in its first exclusive talks in a pension close out deal / bulk annuity. The Solvency ratio will decline to 147% (currently 164%), and the leverage ratio is maintained in its target range of 25 to 30% (on Fitch basis).

In our view, this is a significant acquisition for Phoenix, they have acquired a material book of business on attractive terms that supports the current attractive dividend yield of 6.5%. The question will be whether the deal will allow the stock to be re-rated, with the yield moving closer to its UK life peers yields of Legal’s (6.2% FY18 yield) and Aviva (5.8% yield). While the company deal supports the dividend, the company requires future deals to grow the dividend, but this deal does show Phoenix is capable of finding large, meaningful deals.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

On the SLA side, it's a quick and not terribly tidy way to transform into an asset manager.

Swedish Chef @tadam I went on a (subsidised) holiday to the USSR as a student. The highlight was a visit to a tractor factory. I’m not a spy either.
BE11:25am

SocGen incoming ......

Pharma Snap is loss-making, probably forever. Even if he were given *all* the shares as a bonus, how can they be worth $600m?
BE11:26am

The deal means the disposalof SLA‘s heritage retail, annuity and workplace profits and also leads to an enhanced and expanded partnership agreement between SLA and Phoenix that we expect will lead to further asset management mandates for ASI in the future. Importantly, SLA has also retained the Retail new business, which has been one of the fastest growing divisions of the group in recent years, both in terms of revenue and AuA, and should continue to be ahighly effective form of retail distribution for ASI. Note that SLA will also retain an associate interest in the expanded Phoenix group

Lefevre It was widely reported that Corbyn took a motorcycle holiday to E Germany in the late 70s, he obviously had an interest in the Warsaw Pact region
11:26 am
BE11:26am

We continue to see the low valuation, good growth and high dividend yield as a compelling combination for SLA. Furthermore, we think that the market underappreciates the favourable developments in the Indian businesses – marking to market SLA's Indian operations, the implied valuation of SLA's non-Indian operations is now just around 8x, an unjustified discount, in our view

BE11:27am

And Goldman .....

BE11:27am

If the sale completes, we think SLA would realise the benefits of becoming a capital-light entity, by exchanging its capital-intensive traditional life operations for cash proceeds and an equity stake in the Phoenix Group, while also retaining exposure to its fast-growing, modern UK platform and advice businesses. While we do not take a view on the likelihood of the transaction closing, we would see it as strategically beneficial to SLA and expect the announcement to be well received by the market. The group also reported its FY17 operating results this morning. Key metrics (profits, net flows and dividends) all landed in-line with our/consensus expectations, though we expect this to be overshadowed by the strategic announcement.

Pharma @Lefevre, as you said, I think his support for the Venezuelan regime as recently as 2-3 years ago is more to the point (though the eastern block stuff hardly boosts his credentials to be PM).
11:27 am
PM11:27am

Hmm, fair enough

Soundbuy Warsaw Pact region was popular with those suffering allotment envy.......
BE11:28am

Yep, you get the idea. And I'm sure this all says something very interesting about Martin Gilbert and the asset management industry more generally, but it's Friday and I'm tired so I can't think what it is.

But I guess that's reason enough. Here's Goldman.

BE11:37am

We continue to believe that Pearson faces significant structural challenges in Higher Ed segment with increased competition from both traditional publishing players as well as growth in OER which we expect to drive price deflation (link). In our view, it becomes ever-more important for Pearson to look to leverage its content, brand and scale advantages, before new players are able to build meaningful alternatives on established digital market places. In our view, historical barriers to entry (scale of distribution/production) have fallen and Pearson must pivot quickly to reinvigorate growth and preserve its market position.

While US Higher Education is likely to continue to drag on growth for at least the next couple of years, pockets of growth in the US and improving momentum in Core & Growth should result in the group returning to organic growth in 2018/19. PSON trades on 13.7x 2018E EPS and offers a dividend yield of 2.9%. With higher education still in transition we maintain our Neutral rating and Dec-18 PT of 760p.

We believe a transaction could make strategic sense. Stobart Group and Flybe are well acquainted through franchise agreements and Flybe basing planes at London Southend Airport (LSA). Flybe expanded its presence at LSA in May 2017 launching 11 new routes driving two-thirds of the 25% passenger growth in 1H18A. Plans were also in place for Flybe to base a fourth and fifth aircraft at LSA from Winter 2017 and Summer 2018, adding c.250,000 passengers p.a. A potential takeover of Flybe with Stobart Group taking a non-controlling interest through an investment vehicle could lead to a further uplift in the number of routes flown from LSA, driving passenger growth towards the 5m target by 2022.

Our analysis so far leads us to make the following observations:
– We note that while the company recognized a gain on the revaluation of fixed assets, it was excluded from the adjusted measures provided by the company.
– IP license fees from JVs were determined through independent valuation and have been declining. Unrealized profit largely eliminated in 2015 against the carrying value of the investment with no further elimination in 2016. This is valid from an accounting standpoint although we believe disclosure could be clearer.
– IQE reports upstream purchases from JVs. These are undertaken at cost & the firm indicates they do not impact IQE's profits. IQE serves as anchor customer.
– On JV Investment Accounting, our analysis suggests that company’s disclosure could be significantly clearer. However on accounting, we are able to explain most of the developments in relation to IFRS requirements.

We have analysed IQE’s JV investment accounting
to demonstrate our understanding of the impact of initial contributions, trading between parties, equity method accounting for the losses incurred by JVs and further losses that are unrecognized by IQE as the respective JV investments are already carried at zero value. We consider that the company’s disclosure could be significantly clearer. However on accounting, we are able to explain the development in relation to IFRS requirements. A few questions remain however on matters of disclosure (presentation of revenue for sales to CSC, and potential disclosure of revenue eliminations not recognized in relation to CSDC of £1m). We also await the outcome of KPMG’s audit in relation to whether preference shares might be written down for the further JV losses.
